topic.title: Only one identity by identity service?
topic.body:
Is it not possible to be able to get more than one identity from an identity service(like zeroid)?
That kind of sucks.

1530712796_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
The problem about Zeronet or any other similar "replacement" is, if it ever would be the new standard, the Companies would commercialize and push the development in their powerhungry/fascist agenda. After all the exact same happened to the "normal" Internet, too. Also no one would have thought that it would be possible back then. It's all just a matter of time and popularity.
It's false hope if you really believe there is something better, as long people/politics/money are there, NOTHING will change.

1530873258_1B6sqsG3NZefF44y9TREmf3UqjBDD.body:
> [solved](#comment_22_1KY1YYCNH5sDor7yu19jEr5yMtiZ5QyWwu): the identity is saved in user.json file inside the data directory. Just back this file up somewhere else, then visit the zeroid site with user.json deleted and you will generate a new identity, new user.json. Switch them as needed. Just don't lose them, there is no way to recover them.

Thanks. Nice to know. Actually that should be an essential feature since it makes sense that a user can switch ID to circumvent Metadata collection on a user. In current state a user is pretty well track able.

8_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body:
ZeroNet seriously needs to encrypt all files which get (automatically) downloaded. Just like Freenet or various similar P2P file sharing tools (PD, Share, ..). For easy plausible deniability.
Right now ZeroNet is a absolute NO GO for normal people since they easily risk to get illegal files like CP and other shit on their hard disk without even noticing it.

> [nofish](#comment_1178_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): I think the only secure way is full disk encryption. Even if we would encrypt the files they could be in browser cache/swap/hiberfill

If they were in browser cache it would be by at least an user interaction as in viewing the website. But things like "help distributing" a website, will download all the files without the user interaction like viewing the website. Only when a user want's to see or save the file in cleartext it should get encrypted. Just like Freenet does.

Of course disk encryption is a valid plus, but most users won't/can't/know about it.
